title: Jerry Jeff Walker - Its A Good Night For Singing
description:
It&#039;s A Good Night for Singin&#039;- Jerry Jeff Walker

VRB

From a professional clean vinyl transfer

Out of Print-Never on CD


While It&#039;s a Good Night for Singin&#039; is usually as highly regarded as Viva Terlingua, Ridin&#039; High, or Jerry Jeff Walker, it is not only the equal of those recordings, but perhaps, in its own way, more consistent than all of them -- or therefore their superior. Released in 1976, it has the strongest opening side of any record in Walker&#039;s career. It includes a stomping cover of Tom Waits&#039; "Lookin&#039; for the Heart of Saturday Night," reinvented as a rock roll song with B3s and Fender Rhodes pianos underneath a throbbing bass line (and replaces Waits&#039; own version as definitive), and an urbanized honky tonk read of Butch Hancock&#039;s "Standin&#039; at the Big Hotel" that blows away Joe Ely&#039;s and sounds a lot more like L.A. than Dallas -- which was the original intent of the song -- just to name two. In addition, Walker rounds out side one with the Gary P. Nunn/Karen Brooks classic "Couldn&#039;t Do Nothin&#039; Right," a ballad of resignation and brokenness at leaving a lover who always expected more than there was to give; it also features Lee Clayton&#039;s greatest love song, "Won&#039;t You Give Me One More Chance," Bob Livingstone&#039;s "Head Full of Nothin&#039;," and a stirring, good-timey take on Billy Joe Shaver&#039;s classic "Old Five and Dimers Like Me." What is most notable here is what a great interpreter Walker is on other writers&#039; songs, rather than as a songwriter making them his own in the process. There is only one original on the set, and that&#039;s the immortal "Stoney," which proves Walker hadn&#039;t lost it, but was going for something else entirely. There are a couple of Keith Sykes&#039; tunes on side two, including "Someday I&#039;ll Get out of These Bars" (which Walker hasn&#039;t yet, over 27 years later), Billy C. Farlow&#039;s "Leroy," and Bob Livingstone&#039;s title track, all of which prove, like the first side, that this was indeed an album for singing, not writing, and as such, it stands as one of Walker&#039;s water marks; it endures far better than some of his other material from the same period.

- Thom Jurek, All Music Guide

1976 It&#039;s A Good Night For Singin&#039; (Out of print)

LP, MCA - MCA2022

   1. Looking For The Heart Of Saturday Night (Tom Waits)
   2. Standin&#039; At The Big Hotel (Butch Hancock)
   3. Couldn&#039;t Do Nothin&#039; Right (Gary P. Nunn and Karen Brooks)
   4. Won&#039;t You Give Me One More Chance (Lee Clayton)
   5. Head Full Of Nothin&#039; (Bob Livingston and Rick Fowler)
   6. Old Five And Dimers Like Me (Billy Joe Shaver)
   7. Very Short Time (Keith Sykes)
   8. Some Day I&#039;ll Get Out of These Bars (Keith Sykes)
   9. Stoney (Jerry Jeff Walker)
  10. Dear John Letter Lounge (Rick Cardwell)
  11. Leroy (Billy Callery)
  12. It&#039;s A Good Night For Singing (Bob Livingston)
